724313f-c.title: Manhattan: Waverly Place - Gay Street
724313f-c.text:
(1)
Waverly Place, west from, but no including Gay to Christopher Streets.
Prominent building shown, is an apartment house, No. 45 Christopher Street.
May 1, 1933.
P. L Sperr.
NO REPRDUCTIONB.
(2)
The same, 4lightly westward, showing the triangular Northern Dispensary
at Christopher Street.
May 23, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(3)
An earlier view of the locality seen in No. 2. Buildinga appearing
on Christopher Street are Nos. 49 to 41; the 4-story stable being
No. 47. These were demolished to form the apartment site shown in
later views.
September 24, 1928.
.. Sperr.
NO RsPRODUCTIOS.
724313f-c.folder: Waverly Place & Gay Street, Manhattan, NY

709314f-b.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - Waverly Place
709314f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, aorth of Waverly Place, showing
two 3-story structures that were formerly No. 80 and 82. The
first is reputed to have been at one time ''The Allens'' a notori-
us gambling place. The store's last tenent was the wholesale
hotel chinaware firm of R. Seccos and Sons.
View 2 shows the cleared site of this and adjo'ning build-
ings. The rear tenements are at the back of NOs 58-60 W. 8th St.
The ''Allen'' location would be on the extreme right margin, abut-
ing the side wall of the Van Voorst, the 9-story apartment house
at No. 123-5 Waverly Place.
Overhead appears the distinctive elevation of the apart-
ment dwelling identified as No. 1 Fifth Avenue.
View 1: May 4, 1927
View 2: October 13, 1930
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS
Vie- E1 Ne~EO0
view:2 i N1g. wEO01

709312f-a.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - Waverly Place
709312f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, north across Waverly Place, showing
at Christopher, W. 8th, Greenwich and Sixth Avenue,the
distinctive apartment house, No. 1 Christopher Street,
the new Detention House for Women and the Jefferson
Market Court. The latter contains the clock tower and
appears above the ''g1'' station at 8th Street.
The cleared area in the foreground was necessitated
by subway construction. This transportation facility
will surplant the old ''E1'' line. Demolition of the
latter will occur in 193S.
View 1: March 15, 1932
View2:  February 24, 1933
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS

724312f-a.title: Manhattan: Waverly Place - 6th Avenue
724312f-a.text:
124 Waverly Place, south side, east of Sixth Ave., an old house
remodelled with a north-light studio on the top floor.
About 1915.
International Film Service, Inc.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

709313f-a.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - Waverly Place
709313f-a.text:
Sixth Ave., west side, north from Waverly Place. The tall building
in the background, is the new Detention House for W omen, at the N.W. corner
of Creenwich Ave., and adjoining it (the building with the clock), is the
Jefferson Market Court House. Also note the 8th Street station of the Sixth
Ave. Elevated Line.
March 28, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

709315f-a.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - Waverly Place
709315f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, north from Waverly Place
to W. 8th Street,showing subway construction shacks.
These are grouped at the N. E. corner of Waverly Place.
View 2 shows the explosives there. The photographer is
viewing westward in th's instance. Note the low build-
ings on the far side of the Avenue. No. 3 is an earlier
view of the aforementioned corner.
View 1: March 8, 1939
View 2: February 12, 1939
View 3: April 18, 1937
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS

719999f-a.title: Manhattan: Gay Street - Waverly Place.
719999f-a.text:
14 and 16 Gay Street, west side, between
Waverly Place and Christopher Street. Scotch
weavers inhabited Gay Street over s century ago.
About 20 years ago the one-block street had the
distinction of being the only NIegro street in
the Washington Square neighborhood. This photo
was reproduced on page 100 of the published volume
''Changing New York'' from which the above data is
an excerpt.
November 16, 1937
Berenice Abbott, photo
Federal Art Project
NO R PROEUC IONS
NWg 2~S
719999f-a.folder: Gay Street & Waverly Place., Manhattan, NY

719996f-a.title: Manhattan: Gay Street - Waverly Place
719996f-a.text:
(1)
Gay Street, north from Waverly Place. Gay Street runs only through
the block from Waverly Place (originally West 6th Street) to
Christopher Street, but the bend in it near the northern end,
makes it impossible to see from one end to the other. Gay Street
has been spoken of as the shortest street in New York, but it is
not -- even Weehawken Street is shorter; however, it is probably
the shortest bent street in Manhattan.
September 25, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, four and a half years later. The new One Christopher
Street apartment house, the top of which is seen over the seven-
story loft building in the background, was erected in 1931.
February 24, 1933.
73.z.
P. L. Sperr.  9NG N225
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(3)
A view showing No's. 12 to 18 Gay Street, four private dwellings
on the west side of this short thoroughfare.
SSeptember 4, 1938
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
719996f-a.folder: Gay Street & Waverly Place, Manhattan, NY

709317f-a.text:
389-393 Sixth Ave., west side, north of Waverly Place, showing the

December 24, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

709316f-a.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - Waverly Place
709316f-a.text:
(1)  Sixth Ave., east side, north from Waverly Place, sho ing a clearance
at the N.E. corner of Waverly Place. Also seen is the 8th Street sta-
tion of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line. Note, in the center of the view,
the entrance to the Eighth Ave. Hiunicipally owned Independemt Subway
System.
April 13, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, after further demolition.
June 5, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(3)  The same, at a later date, and showing on the left, the new Detent-
ion House for Women, (at the N.W. corner of Greenwich Ave)., and the
tower of the Jefferson Market Cturt House, adjoining it.
February 7, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REP(ODUCTIONS.
